description:
Ryou Saeba and his long-suffering partner Kaori are out to make the streets of Shinjuku safe for the weak, the poor, the down- trodden, the... Well, actually, Ryou’s just hoping for a little mokkori from a grateful client. And Kaori’s just hoping her 100-ton hammer is big enough to get Ryou’s mind off the girls and on his job. With a bevy of beautiful women and a host of dastardly villains hanging around, City Hunter’s got to be ready for any kind of action!

(Source: Discotek)

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Cars
tags.description: Centers around the use of automotive vehicles.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Bar
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a bar.

tags.name: Swimming
tags.description: Centers around the sport of swimming.

tags.name: Scuba Diving
tags.description: Prominently features characters diving with the aid of special breathing equipment.

title.native: シティーハンター ベイシティウォーズ
シティーハンター 百万ドルの陰謀

node.description:
[Official Website](http://www.hojo-tsukasa.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/hojo_official)

He studied technical design at Kyushu Sangyo University, where he began to draw manga. Hojo is a mentor of Takehiko Inoue (creator of Slam Dunk) and a longtime friend of Tetsuo Hara (creator of Fist of the North Star). Designed the character Reina, who was introduced in the 2006 movie Hokuto no Ken: Raō Den - Jun'ai no Shō.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%93%E3%81%A0%E3%81%BE%E5%85%BC%E5%97%A3) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenji_Kodama)

Kenji Kodama is a Japanese director and storyboard artist. He is best known for being one of the main directors on the long-running anime [Detective Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/235/), as well as the [City Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1470/) series and [Lupin III: Part III](https://anilist.co/anime/1426/).

Married to animator [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/).

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/木村貴宏)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/平野靖士)

John Ledford is an entrepreneur and leader in the North American anime industry. In 1992, he founded A.D. Vision (ADV), paving the way for other businesses and the exponential growth anime has had within North America. With ADV's success, Ledford turned his sights to making the imaginative world of anime even more accessible with Anime Network's founding, North America’s first cable TV network dedicated to anime. He later partnered with Kadokawa Publishing and began Newtype USA with translated Japanese content and exclusive U.S. material related to all things anime, manga, and model reviews. This endeavor expanded into ADV Manga, which obtained licensing and publishing rights for hundreds of Japanese manga and Korean manhwa.

In 2008, Ledford founded a new anime-focused company called Sentai Filmworks (Sentai). Since its founding, Sentai provides thousands of hours of content across traditional and digital platforms. Sentai’s dedication to bringing captivating stories, including acclaimed titles such as Grave of the Fireflies, Ninja Scroll, and High School of the Dead to audiences, is ongoing.

Ledford’s most recent success is with the 2017 founding of the streaming service HIDIVE. Since launching, HIDIVE is now available via a web browser, mobile devices, gaming platforms, and more. HIDIVE offers new simulcasts every season, an ever-growing collection of dubs, and exclusive titles. The service features DUBCAST SM editions, early access local-language dubs of simulcasts directly produced by HIDIVE, as early as two weeks after the original Japanese broadcast.

For nearly thirty years now, Ledford continues his goal to further the expansion of anime and the Japanese culture as a whole.

A co-founder and a board member of [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Upon graduating from high school, Kawamoto was first employed in the making and designing of precision machinery. During this early period, he became interested in becoming an animator due to the ongoing [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/)'s [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s amateur [Daicon](https://anilist.co/anime/2724/) films. In particular, [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s work was a major influence.

After graduating, he applied for a small sub-contracting studio called Group Donguri and was accepted. In 1986, he made his debut in Yasuhiko's 1986 film [Arion](https://anilist.co/anime/791/). During the production he was mentored by the character designer [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/), with whom he would later work with on multiple occasions, including being her assistant in [Venus Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/544/), which was also written and directed by Yasuhiko. After this Kawamoto worked on numerous series by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), most notably as a character designer on the Gundam entries, [Stardust Memory](https://anilist.co/anime/84/) and [The 08th MS Team](https://anilist.co/anime/81/), as well as the internationally acclaimed [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/).

In 1998, he co-founded Bones with fellow Sunrise staff members [Masahiko Minami](https://anilist.co/staff/101519/) and [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). Some of the more recent works he has provided designs for include [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Ghost Slayers Ayashi](https://anilist.co/anime/1587/), [Noragami](https://anilist.co/anime/20447/) and [Kekkai Sensen](https://anilist.co/anime/20727/).

**Non-anime staff credits:**
~!
- Character Design - "Gigantic Drive" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam A year of War" (Video game)

- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam F91 Formula Senki 0122" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Return of Zion" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Senki" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE Be Eliminate Yesterday" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Wonder Project J" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Robot Alchemic Drive" (Video game)
- Assistant Chief Animation Director - "OVER THE MONOCHROME RAINBOW" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation for "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam PERFECT ONE YEAR WAR" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Serial Experiments Lain" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Spiral Zone" (ep 5)!~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/evo_s10) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大平晋也) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=shinya_ohira)

Shinya Oohira is one of the most talented and recognized animators in the world of anime. His animation style includes using exaggerating motion, manipulating gravity and balance with use of different perspective shots, lots of rapid camera movement and unconventional angles. With his boldly distorted and vigorous drawing style, his cuts are unique and instantly recognizable.

He has worked as an animator for over thirty years. His early work in the 80's mainly consisted of action and effects cuts. He bounced around several studios, including [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), and [Pierrot](https://anilist.co/studio/1/). His early cuts include [Gall Force 2: Destruction](https://anilist.co/anime/2061/), for which he animated a laser beam with a distinctly loose and vivid sense of movement. With its smooth animation and wavy motion pattern, the cut has a lively fluidity to it that can be seen as the first step towards Oohira's current distinctive visuality. He used the same approach on his smoke effects for [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) and a flood for [Angel Cop](https://anilist.co/anime/1351/). His style truly came into fruition when he started applying this to solid objects – especially people. The earliest such case is his cut in the fourth episode in [The Hakkenden: Shin Shou](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/). The Oohira "wobble," is perhaps his most distinct trademark: the animated objects expand and compress in a wobbling manner.

Aspired to become an animator after having seen [Masahito Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/138566/)'s work on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/).

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Tetsuya Komuro, also known as TK, is a Japanese keyboardist, guitarist, singer, songwriter and music producer.     He is recognized as being the most successful producer in Japanese music history and introduced dance music to the Japanese mainstream. He was also a former owner of the discothèque Velfarre located in Roppongi, Tokyo.    He is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in pop throughout the 1990s.    In the Oricon singles chart of April 15, 1996, he monopolized all the Top 5 positions as the songwriter and producer, a world record. In 1995 he monopolized all Top 3 positions of the copyright distribution rankings for the JASRAC Award, a record in Japan's music history.    At his peak as a record producer the artists he predominantly produced for came to be known as TK Family and at one time included Namie Amuro, hitomi, TRF, Tomomi Kahala and Ami Suzuki amongst others.    To date, singles composed by him have sold more than 70 million, singles whose lyrics he wrote have sold more than 42 million, and all in all records produced by him have sold more than 170 million in Japan alone.
Joined Audio Planning U in 1982, where he studied under [Yasuo Urakami](https://anilist.co/staff/111277/).

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.
Mitsuharu Miyamae is an art director.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/3028907837)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神村幸子)

She is noted for her work with Sunrise, where she was the supervising animator and character designer for the [City Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1470/) series.

Prior to working at [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), she previously worked at Toei Animation and Walt Disney Animation Japan. Kamimura adapted characters and artwork for the [The Heroic Legend of Arslan](https://anilist.co/anime/1762/) anime and designed them for the Brain Lord video game, as well as producing illustrations for many Japanese novels.

Kamimura's artbooks are rare and sought-after by Anime Otaku.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/今西隆志)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/今西隆志)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/今西隆志)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%93%E3%81%A0%E3%81%BE%E5%85%BC%E5%97%A3) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenji_Kodama)

Kenji Kodama is a Japanese director and storyboard artist. He is best known for being one of the main directors on the long-running anime [Detective Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/235/), as well as the [City Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1470/) series and [Lupin III: Part III](https://anilist.co/anime/1426/).

Married to animator [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/日暮裕一)

Yuuichi Higurashi was a Japanese scriptwriter for TV dramas and animations.

After joining [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/Sunrise) and serving as a production assistant, he made his debut as a director in the 10th episode of [Aoki Ryuusei SPT Layzner](https://anilist.co/anime/3079/Aoki-Ryuusei-SPT-Layzner/).

Date of Birth: June 24th, 1931
Birthplace: Paris, France
Date of Death: November 12th, 2013
